{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3554565,"name":"","username":"SirFire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sirfire/{size}/222590_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T23:04:48.529Z","cooked":"

Hey there CD!

We’re trying to wire up this older Grayhill encoder, and need some help. I havent found any wiring diagrams or anything, or if we have, its been for wiring it to a motor controller or something. How do these things wire up to a roboRIO?

20250311_1601141920×2560 285 KB

20250311_1600593060×4080 1020 KB

For future reference, the search terms you need are the manufacturer, the product series (63R) and the counts per revolution (256).

Searching ChiefDelphi yielded this.

Searching the Internet yielded this, this and this.

Check your robot programming library of choice to see if a routine exists for quadrature encoders, and post a link to the documentation.

Ah perfect, I think I see now, I was confused by the fact of it having 5 pins because other encoders we’ve used have only had four, but now I see that Pin 4 is apparently useless, labeled as “no contact.” Im assuming we can now just plug 5V, Output A, and GND into one DIO pin and Output B into a second DIO pin and use WPILib’s Encoder class to code it, correct?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T17:36:39.996Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":33.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495221,"topic_slug":"grayhill-encoder-wiring-help","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":235,"username":"Tristan_Lall","name":"Tristan Lall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tristan_lall/{size}/97_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54317,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Main Programmer Dude | 8551"},"post_url":"/t/grayhill-encoder-wiring-help/495221/3","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3555324,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T18:22:33.006Z","cooked":"
SirFire:

Pin 4 is apparently useless

If you plug in upside down, the 5v power on pin 2 goes to the unconnected pin 4 - a modicum of fool-proofing.

Are you saying that both pin 2 and pin 4 need/can accept 5V? In that case, would it still work just being plugged into one ground port?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T20:42:44.075Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":27,"readers_count":26,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495221,"topic_slug":"grayhill-encoder-wiring-help","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54317,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Main Programmer Dude | 8551"},"post_url":"/t/grayhill-encoder-wiring-help/495221/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3555524,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T21:32:52.329Z","cooked":"

No.

He is saying that with a 5 pin connector properly populated with 4 wires, if you plug that connector in right-side-up everything will work.

But if you mistakenly plug it in upsidedown (which may not be obvious based on connector geometry), the device will not be hurt by putting power where it shouldn’t, because the 5v supply wire will be connected to the NC pin of the device, keeping everything an open circuit.

It’s an electromechanical method of “foolproofing”, keeping the people assembling the device and wiring from accidentally doing it wrong and causing damage.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-12T21:32:52.329Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":21,"readers_count":20,"score":24.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":495221,"topic_slug":"grayhill-encoder-wiring-help","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54317,"username":"SirFire","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sirfire/{size}/222590_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/grayhill-encoder-wiring-help/495221/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3555796,"name":"Tristan Lall","username":"Tristan_Lall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tristan_lall/{size}/97_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-13T02:53:39.123Z","cooked":"
Jwal:

He is saying that with a 5 pin connector properly populated with 4 wires, if you plug that connector in right-side-up everything will work.

But if you mistakenly plug it in upsidedown (which may not be obvious based on connector geometry), the device will not be hurt by putting power where it shouldn’t, because the 5v supply wire will be connected to the NC pin of the device, keeping everything an open circuit.

The different pin configuration appears to be the main difference between the 63K (4-pin) and 63R (5-pin) encoders. They refer to the 5-pin version as having a polarized connection…though it is probably more accurately a human-error-resistant connection.
